ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my knowledge of the future energy landscape of America, and my knowledge of carbon emissions from relative energy sources. I also learned a lot about upcoming/promising/potential energy solutions, and what solutions are not feasible.
The benefits of green energy and the applications of such in the real world
I learned about different renewable energy sources. I also learned about the importance of natural gas as it is currently very important to energy generation.
General overview of renewable energies
Learned basic info about energy usage in US and world

This course allowed me to understand the basic science behind energy production and usage while understanding its relevance to today's energy use. While the course allowed for rudimentary understanding of the concepts, it provided for a deeper dive into the concepts in the final project and psets,  which carefully aligned with the material.
Presentation and overarching scientific knowledge nothing too deep
learned about energy storage and delivery, including green energy

Skills in research using Quicksearch & Library, finding credible energy statistics and sources, and presenting/working with peers on the final project.
I definitely developed more knowledge on the nuances of energy policy, the energy sector, fossil fuels, infrastructural considerations and current limitations of renewables, life cycle analysis, basic knowledge on energy science and mathematics and much more!
This course taught me in-depth, how I can survey the internet for information regarding competing and varying information on the technology involved with energy in relation to the enviroment.
I learned a lot more about technology and science applied to common phenomena and tech in a lot of depth.
I learned a lot about methods that help the environment and how some environmentally-friendly technologies aren't as efficient.
A good understanding of energy flows/the energy balance in the US and how it is changing

I learned about trends in energy, different programs and systems at Yale, and about my project topic for the final presentation. It was also interesting and worthwhile to discuss EV charging capacity/needs from renewable energy.

Many topics, though, I thought were explored at only surface level.
Insights into energy technology and barriers to sustainable energy transition.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the strengths of the course was the wide breadth of information and knowledge that it provided. One weakness of the course was the material on the psets was not always indicative of the material presented in lecture, which is one improvement that I might make. One major benefit of the course is that it wasn't information overload like some of the other courses at Yale, so it was possible to really focus in and internalize what we were learning.

Strengths - insightful final project
Weakness - lecture material was often hard to follow/didn't seem to be concentrated
The course was strong in relating concepts to our current lives, but it was sometimes a little boring as it lacked student interaction.
The course material was pretty dry and the lectures were slow and repetitive. The midterm was very hard because there were way too many questions.

Strengths: Very accessible to everyone, limited prior knowledge needed
Weaknesses: Very broad overview of renewable energies, if you do have prior experience in this field you will likely be quite bored in this class
Interesting material but kind of bland lectures; manageable workload

While the content is interesting, once there was no incentive to take notes, it was difficult to pay attention in class due to Zoom fatigue. The course did a good job at providing basic concepts in energy, but it was difficult to remain engaged.
Zoom was the biggest weakness, the hands on side of things could have been helpful
lectures got a better repetitive and tedious. I had hoped to be more engaged. that said, the assignments were clear and straight forward -- nothing too difficult.

Strengths were organization, amazing guest lectures, hands-on opportunities, and interesting content ranging in environmental policy, science, and justice. More strengths than weaknesses and minimal improvements. 

Few improvements would be to ensure that the PowerPoint posted before class aligns with the content during the lecture. At times minor or major alterations would be made making the lecture difficult to follow. As for the midterm, maybe a clearer outline of the main topic.
More connection between lectures and PSETs.

I think this class would have been more enjoyable in person, as the lectures could often be a bit boring and let to me zoning out. I think if we had been in person this semester I would have been more engaged, but of course this isn't anyone's fault. There was a lot of help and support from both the TAs and the teacher.

Strength: fun to learn and had lots of opportunities to ask questions
Weakness: somethings the lecture had too much information in one lesson, wish it was spread out more
Professor Prober understood the material but was not a particularly engaging/high-energy lecturer

The lectures are dry and not very well organized. It seemed like we would often watch videos multiple times or return to very specific topics (and have the same discussions over and over again), and the lectures were a little bit slow and rambling. The best part of the class was the guest speakers.

There was also low engagement from the class in general, with hardly anyone using their cameras or contributing class. This made the class not very engaging to be in.

The strengths of the class are the guest speakers and the final project, which was fun and worthwhile.
I enjoyed the content of the course very much. I could have spent less time in class and throughout the semester on the project for more time in lecture to explore topics.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course transitioned well to the COVID-19 pandemic, and its flexibility and accommodations for students due to COVID-19 allowed me to focus on learning the material rather than being extremely stressed because I've spent all of my education for the past year and a quarter on my computer with little to no social life. This class was a bright light of learning while some of my other classes made no accommodations for the difficulties of the COVID-19 pandemic.
The virtual lectures worked fine
Sometimes the professor would ask questions to the class, but honestly there were few practices that allowed for virtual engagement.
I didn't like that the lecture was not recorded, there really was no reason for it to be synchronous
Virtual lectures were good but not super engaging (monotonous)
Zoom learning made it extremely difficult to remain focused.
virtual office hours were good!
Making use of breakout room feature for group projects, raise-hand feature, and periodical verbal cues for questions or comments.
A clearer connection between what we spoke about in class and the other work in the course

The zoom helped the powerpoint to be seen by everybody.
I wished the lessons were recorded so students could go back to them before the exam.
Using breakout rooms to facilitate discussion could have been helpful

Prof. Prober is very flexible and makes sure that no one is procrastinating on assignments and the final project. But the lectures, especially over Zoom, just weren't effective in making the class pay attention.
Group projects were a good way to engage with other students despite the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this class to any student who wants to learn about a variety of potential energy solutions, many of which will play a role in our sustainable future.
If you are interested in the subject matter then yes

I would recomend this course to non STEM majors seeking to fulfill a science requirement as it is not super calculation heavy. However, because of the platform this course was given, I feel as though I did not get the full experience of the course. Also since I did not necessarily enjoy this course over zoom, I would caution students to take this course online.
Only to someone wanting a very general introductory course to renewable energy, anyone with prior experience/knowledge should not take this course
Definitely. Good course (if not super exciting) and not too much work
Yes. It is a great course for students who are non-STEM, or exploring STEM field, to learn about the basics of energy studies and then see whether they are interested in diving deeper into the field.
Yes, for those not crazy about science and needing their distributional requirements m filled this class is perfect, a few problem sets and a final presentation that you cannot fail.

I just needed a science credit, and this certainly wasn't the worst. It was less interesting than I had hoped, but also less work than expected. the one midterm was not nearly as hard as the problem sets, and the final project wasn't anything too complicated

I would recommend the course to another student because it was a good mix of science and policy. The content was fun and manageable, with a lot of interesting case studies during the lectures.  Though I would warn that the problem sets can be calculation and math-heavy, it was tolerable as long as you paid attention to the examples given in class, the math equations lecture, and frequented TA help sessions.
Yes, this course was very interesting for those. interested in energy technology

Yes, if you would like an intro class to see if you want to major in an environmental-focused major, you should take this class. Or if you just want to learn more about truth about eco-friendly power sources, then take this class.
Yes, but only if they are interested in a non-technical approach to renewables and energy systems

Unfortunately, no. The class material scrapes at interesting topics in energy, but seemed like a lot of time that wasn't used maximally for discussion/exploration of energy topics. Lectures can be frustratingly dry and slow. 

If you are really looking for an easy science credit, this would be a good (but not very thrilling/engaging) choice. The math is not too difficult, and the concepts are easy enough to grasp. 

The best parts of the course are the guest lecturers and the final project. Professor Prober is also a really nice person, but the lectures are just hard to sit through.
I would recommend this course to another student who is very interested in sustainability, the environment, or energy technology.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I had to watch one recorded lecture, but other than that one occasion I attended every lecture live.
N/A
Mostly live virtual lectures.
None
Live virtual lectures.
none
N/A
Help sessions with TF before pset was due on zoom
None
